Plant Part Affected: Leaves, stems, and occasionally fruits (in advanced infection stages)
Symptoms Description: Alternaria Leaf Spot begins as tiny brown or black specks on leaves that gradually enlarge into circular lesions with distinct concentric rings resembling a target pattern. The center of the spots becomes dry, brittle, and sometimes gray. Severe infections cause yellowing, leaf curling, early leaf drop, reduced photosynthesis, and overall weakening of plant growth. In humid conditions, a dark, velvety fungal layer may appear on the lesion surface.
Season/Trigger Conditions:
* Warm temperatures (25–30°C)
* High humidity levels
* Frequent rainfall or overhead irrigation
* Poor air movement and dense plant spacing
* Wet soil conditions
* Presence of infected plant debris
* Plant stress due to nutrient deficiency or drought
Natural Resolution:
1. Remove and destroy infected leaves to prevent spread.
2. Improve air circulation by providing proper spacing or light pruning.
3. Avoid wetting the foliage; water only at the base of the plant.
4. Ensure adequate sunlight to reduce moisture on leaf surfaces.
5. Spray neem oil every 7 days to slow the fungal growth naturally.
6. Apply compost tea or organic microbial solutions to strengthen plant immunity.
7. Keep soil clean by removing fallen leaves or debris where fungus survives.
8. Rotate crops each season to interrupt the fungal life cycle.
9. Apply a light mulch layer to prevent soil splash transmitting spores.
Chemical Resolution:
Use any ONE of the recommended fungicides (according to label dosage):

* Mancozeb 75% WP– Broad-spectrum control
* Chlorothalonil 75% WP – Effective for leaf spot management
* Copper Oxychloride 50% WP – Good for early to mid-infections
* Azoxystrobin + Difenoconazole (combination fungicide) – Best for severe infections
* Propiconazole 25% EC – Systemic fungicide for fast action

Spray interval: Every 7–10 days until symptoms decline.
Important: Rotate fungicides to prevent resistance buildup
Preventive Measures:
* Maintain proper plant spacing for good airflow.
* Water in the morning and avoid wetting leaves.
* Remove dry, damaged, or infected foliage regularly.
* Apply preventive neem oil spray every 10–14 days.
* Enhance soil health with organic compost to boost immunity.
* Avoid continuous planting of the same crop in one spot.
* Use drip irrigation to reduce leaf wetness.
* Keep the growing area clean from dead leaves and weeds.
Detection Method:
* Visual inspection for brown or black spots with concentric rings.
* Check for early leaf yellowing and defoliation.
* Use a magnifying lens to observe fungal growth on the underside of leaves.
* Laboratory confirmation using fungal culture or PCR diagnosis (optional).
Impact on Yield:
* Decreased photosynthesis from leaf damage
* Premature leaf drop reducing plant energy
* Smaller, poor-quality fruits
* Overall yield losses ranging from **20% to 50%** in severe outbreaks
Stage of Plant Growth Affected: Affects all growth stages, but damage is greatest during **mid and late growth stages** when foliage is dense.
Region/Geography:
Widely observed across tropical, subtropical, and temperate regions, especially in:

* India
* Southeast Asia
* Africa
* South America
* Mediterranean regions
Cultural control:
Cultural control methods focus on modifying growing practices to reduce the survival, spread, and infection rate of the Alternaria fungus. The following cultural strategies are highly effective:

* Use disease-free seeds and healthy planting material.
* Maintain proper plant spacing to improve airflow and reduce humidity around leaves.
* Water plants early in the morning and avoid overhead irrigation to keep foliage dry.
* Rotate crops regularly and avoid planting susceptible crops in the same soil every season.
* Remove and destroy infected leaves, fallen debris, and weeds that may harbor fungal spores.
* Ensure proper field sanitation by cleaning tools and equipment before use.
* Improve soil fertility with well-decomposed organic compost to enhance plant immunity.
* Avoid excessive nitrogen fertilizers, as they promote dense foliage susceptible to infection.
* Provide adequate sunlight by pruning overcrowded branches or thinning dense canopies.
* Use mulch to prevent soil splash from spreading fungal spores onto leaves.

Plant Part Affected: Leaves, stems, young shoots, buds, flowers, and sometimes roots (depending on species)
Symptoms Description: Aphids are tiny soft-bodied insects (green, black, brown, or yellow) that suck plant sap from tender parts. Infested leaves become curled, yellow, sticky, and distorted. The insects produce a sugary substance called honeydew, which leads to sooty mold growth. Heavy infestations stunt plant growth, weaken shoots, and cause flower and fruit deformities. Ants are often seen farming aphids due to honeydew secretion.
Season/Trigger Conditions:
* Warm, dry climate
* Excess nitrogen fertilizer
* Dense or overcrowded planting
* Poor airflow
* Presence of ants (which protect aphids)
* Weak plant health or stress conditions
* Lack of natural predators (ladybugs, lacewings)
* Young, tender plant growth
Natural Resolution:
1. Wash aphids off with a strong jet of water.
2. Remove heavily infested leaves or soft shoots.
3. Apply neem oil every 5–7 days.
4. Spray mild soap solution (liquid soap + water).
5. Encourage natural predators (ladybirds, lacewings).
6. Remove weeds and alternative host plants.
7. Avoid overuse of nitrogen fertilizers.
8. Use reflective mulches to repel aphids.
Chemical Resolution:
Use any ONE (follow recommended dosing):

* Imidacloprid 17.8% SL – Strong systemic control
* Thiamethoxam 25% WG – Fast systemic action
* Lambda-cyhalothrin 5% EC – Foliar spray contact control
* Acephate 75% SP – Effective for heavy infestations
* Spirotetramat 15% OD – Long-lasting systemic control

Spray interval: Every 10–14 days if needed.
Important: Rotate insecticides to avoid resistance.
Preventive Measures:
* Maintain plant spacing and airflow.
* Apply neem oil regularly as a preventive spray.
* Use yellow sticky traps for early detection.
* Avoid excessive nitrogen fertilization.
* Keep area free from weeds and soft-tissue host plants.
* Encourage beneficial insects like ladybugs and lacewings.
* Control ant movement around plants (ants protect aphids).
Detection Method:
* Visual observation of clusters of small insects on young shoots and undersides of leaves
* Sticky honeydew on leaves
* Black sooty mold growing on honeydew
* Leaf curling, yellowing, and stunted shoots
* Ant trails climbing plants (indicating aphids above)
Impact on Yield:
* Reduced photosynthesis due to leaf damage
* Poor fruit formation and flower drop
* Stunted plant growth
* Increased disease susceptibility (virus transmission)
* Yield loss ranges from **15–40%** in severe infestati
Stage of Plant Growth Affected: Mostly affects early and mid-growth stages, especially where new tender shoots develop. Severe infestations can affect plants at any stage
Region/Geography:
Aphids occur worldwide, especially in:

* India
* Southeast Asia
* Europe
* Africa
* North & South America
* Mediterranean regions
Cultural control:
Cultural practices to naturally reduce aphid infestation:

* Use resistant or tolerant plant varieties whenever possible.
* Maintain proper spacing to reduce humidity and prevent crowding.
* Water plants adequately to keep them vigorous and less susceptible.
* Prune overcrowded branches to improve ventilation and sunlight exposure.
* Remove weeds that act as alternate hosts for aphids.
* Avoid over-fertilizing with nitrogen, which encourages soft, aphid-friendly growth.
* Use reflective mulches (silver/white) to repel aphids from plant surfaces.
* Sanitize tools and equipment to prevent cross-contamination.
* Remove plant residues and fallen debris after harvest to reduce overwintering sites.
* Implement crop rotation to break pest buildup in soil.

In moist conditions, a fine, grayish fungal growth may appear on the lesion surface. The disease weakens plants, reduces photosynthesis, and affects overall vigor.

* High humidity or prolonged leaf wetness
* Frequent rainfall or overhead irrigation
* Dense plant spacing
* Poor airflow around foliage
* Presence of infected plant debris in the soil
* Nutrient-stressed or weakened plants
Natural Resolution:

2. Improve airflow by pruning or increasing spacing.
3. Water at the base of the plant; avoid wetting leaves.
4. Increase sunlight exposure to help dry foliage quickly.
5. Spray neem oil every 7 days to slow fungal progress.
6. Apply compost tea or bio-fungus sprays to strengthen plant immunity.
7. Clean the soil surface by removing fallen leaves and debris.
8. Rotate crops to disrupt the Cercospora life cycle.
9. Use light mulching to prevent soil splash transmitting spores.

* Copper Oxychloride 50% WP – Controls early infection
* Azoxystrobin 250 SC – Strong systemic fungicide
* Difenoconazole 25% EC – Effective against Cercospora species
* Hexaconazole 5% EC – Systemic and long-lasting effect

* Apply balanced fertilization—avoid excess nitrogen.
* Mulch soil lightly to prevent spore splash onto lower leaves.
* Ensure proper drainage to avoid standing water.
* Keep tools and pruning equipment sanitized.

Plant Part Affected: Leaves, young shoots, growing tips, flower buds, and sometimes fruits (indirect effects)
Symptoms Description: Leaf Curl Virus causes severe curling, twisting, and upward cupping of young leaves. Leaves become thick, brittle, yellowish, and deformed. Shoots show stunted growth, reduced branching, and shortened internodes. The plant appears dwarfed with weak flowering and poor fruit formation. In advanced cases, the entire canopy becomes distorted, reducing plant vigor drastically. Whiteflies are the main vectors transmitting the virus.
Season/Trigger Conditions:
* Hot and dry climate
* High whitefly population
* Poor field sanitation
* Overcrowded planting
* Weedy surroundings
* Early-season infection (most damaging)
* Tender new plant growth (highly susceptible)
* Continuous cropping of susceptible hosts
Natural Resolution:
1. Remove and destroy infected leaves or heavily affected shoots.
2. Control whiteflies using neem oil or soap sprays.
3. Improve ventilation by pruning overly dense foliage.
4. Water plants at the base; avoid creating humid microclimates.
5. Apply neem-based extracts (weekly) to suppress whitefly activity.
6. Keep the field free of weed hosts such as wild tomato or nightshade.
7. Improve plant nutrition with organic compost to strengthen immunity.
8. Use sticky yellow traps to reduce whitefly attraction.

Note: Viral diseases cannot be cured—natural management reduces spread and severity.
Chemical Resolution:
Chemical control focuses on whitefly management (virus vector):

Use any ONE of the following insecticides:

* Imidacloprid 17.8% SL – Strong systemic vector control
* Thiamethoxam 25% WG – Fast knockdown of whiteflies
* Pyriproxyfen 10% EC – Effective on whitefly nymph stages
* Spirotetramat 15% OD – Long-lasting systemic control
* Buprofezin 25% SC – Growth regulator for whitefly nymphs

Spray interval: Every 7–10 days depending on infestation.
Important: Rotate insecticides to avoid resistance.
Preventive Measures:
* Use virus-free seedlings or certified planting material.
* Install yellow sticky traps to monitor and control whiteflies early.
* Maintain adequate plant spacing for airflow.
* Keep field/garden free from weeds and alternate hosts.
* Cover nursery seedlings with netting to prevent vector entry.
* Apply neem oil or botanical extracts weekly as preventive sprays.
* Avoid planting susceptible crops near heavily infected fields.
* Improve soil fertility to reduce stress in young plants.
Detection Method:
* Visual observation of upward leaf curling, thickened leaves, and yellowing
* Stunted shoots and poor flowering
* High presence of whiteflies under leaves
* Sticky traps for vector monitoring
* Laboratory PCR test (optional) for confirming the virus
Impact on Yield:
* Reduced leaf area → lower photosynthesis
* Poor root, shoot, and flower development
* Smaller and fewer fruits
* In severe early infections, plants may produce almost no yield
* Yield losses range from 30% to 80% depending on crop and stage
Stage of Plant Growth Affected: All stages, but early-stage infection results in the most severe damage and highest yield loss.
Region/Geography:
Widespread in tropical and subtropical regions, including:

* India
* Southeast Asia
* Africa
* South & Central America
* Middle East
* Southern Europe
Cultural control:
Cultural practices to reduce Leaf Curl spread:

* Follow strict crop rotation with non-host crops.
* Use whitefly-proof netting in nurseries.
* Remove and destroy infected plants early to reduce virus load.
* Maintain weed-free surroundings (weeds harbor virus + whiteflies).
* Use mulches to reduce soil splash and stabilize microclimate.
* Avoid continuous monocropping of susceptible crops like chilli and tomato.
* Promote natural enemies such as ladybirds, lacewings, and parasitoids.
* Avoid working in the field when foliage is wet to prevent vector movement.
* Prune overcrowded branches to reduce humidity and increase airflow.

Plant Part Affected: Young shoots, stems, flower buds, fruits (internal and external damage)
Symptoms Description: Eggplant Fruit and Shoot Borer causes severe deformities and internal damage in eggplant. Larvae bore into tender shoots, causing wilting and drying of young branches. In fruits, the larvae make holes near the calyx and feed internally, leaving tunnels filled with excreta. Infested fruits become deformed, discolored, lightweight, and unmarketable. The insect causes “hidden damage,” as external symptoms are often minimal while internal fruit tissue is destroyed.
Season/Trigger Conditions:
* Warm temperatures (25–32°C)
* High humidity
* Dense plantation without pruning
* Continuous eggplant cropping
* Presence of weeds and alternate hosts
* Peak population during flowering and fruiting season
* Poor field sanitation
Natural Resolution:
1. Handpick and destroy infested shoots and fruits.
2. Remove larvae found in freshly bored shoots or fruits.
3. Use pheromone traps to catch male moths.
4. Install light traps in the evening to reduce moth population.
5. Encourage natural enemies like Trichogramma parasitoids and ladybirds.
6. Prune and destroy wilted or bored shoots promptly.
7. Keep the field weed-free to eliminate alternate hosts.
8. Practice regular harvesting to remove infested fruits early.
Chemical Resolution:
Use any ONE (as per recommended dosage):

* Emamectin Benzoate 5% SG – Very effective on larvae
* Spinosad 45% SC – Controls early larval stages
* Flubendiamide 20% WG – Long-lasting caterpillar control
* Lambda-cyhalothrin 5% EC – Effective foliar spray
* Chlorantraniliprole 18.5% SC – Highly effective against borers

Spray interval: Every 10–12 days during fruiting stage.
Note: Rotate insecticides to avoid resistance
Preventive Measures:
* Use resistant eggplant varieties where available.
* Remove infested fruits and shoots regularly.
* Install pheromone traps @ 40–50 traps per hectare.
* Maintain proper spacing for good airflow.
* Use nylon netting around nursery seedlings.
* Apply neem seed kernel extract (NSKE 5%) or neem oil weekly.
* Practice timely pruning to open the plant canopy.
* Avoid continuous monocropping of eggplant in the same field.
Detection Method:
* Entry holes on fruits near calyx.
* Wilting or drying of tender shoots.
* Internal fruit boring with frass (insect waste).
* Pheromone trap catches used to detect adult moths.
* Visual inspection of immature shoots for larval entry.
Impact on Yield:
* Internal fruit damage → unmarketable produce
* Reduced fruit size and weight
* Severe infestations may reduce yield by 30%–70%
* Loss of plant vigor due to damaged shoots
Stage of Plant Growth Affected:
All stages, but most severe during:

* Flowering stage
* Fruit development stage
Region/Geography:
Widely distributed across eggplant-growing regions:

* India
* Southeast Asia
* Bangladesh
* Africa
* Middle East
* South America
* Southern China
Cultural control:
Cultural strategies to reduce EFSB infestation:

* Use crop rotation with non-host crops (legumes, cereals).
* Plant trap crops like marigold around the field.
* Prune lower branches to improve sunlight penetration.
* Maintain field sanitation—remove all crop residues after harvest.
* Avoid late sowing which increases pest risk.
* Use fine-mesh insect nets in nurseries and early stages.
* Destroy infested fruits by burying them deep or burning.
* Remove alternate weed hosts such as Solanum species.
* Regularly monitor with pheromone traps for early detection.
* Apply balanced fertilizers—avoid excessive nitrogen.

Plant Part Affected: Leaves (primary), stems, petioles, sometimes young fruits depending on crop
Symptoms Description: Downy Mildew begins as pale-yellow or light-green irregular spots on the upper leaf surface. These spots enlarge and turn brown or purple. On the underside of leaves, a characteristic grayish-white to purplish downy growth (fungal-like spores) appears in humid conditions. Infected leaves curl downward, dry prematurely, and fall off. Severe infection leads to defoliation, weak plant growth, poor fruit set, and reduced yield.

* High relative humidity (>85%)
* Prolonged leaf wetness due to dew, fog, or rain
* Poor air circulation
* Dense planting
* Overhead irrigation
* Cloudy weather lasting several days

2. Improve ventilation by pruning overcrowded foliage.
3. Reduce leaf wetness—water at the base early in the morning.
4. Increase sunlight exposure by adjusting canopy density.
5. Apply neem oil or garlic extract weekly to slow disease spread.
6. Remove plant debris from soil surface.
7. Improve soil drainage to avoid humidity buildup.
8. Rotate crops with non-host species to break the disease cycle.
9. Use resistant varieties, if available.

* Propamocarb 722 SL – Strong systemic action for oomycetes
* Copper Oxychloride 50% WP – Effective in early stages

Plant Part Affected: Leaves (primarily), stems, seedlings, and sometimes roots (species-specific)
Symptoms Description: Flea Beetles are small, shiny, jumping beetles that cause tiny round holes (shot-hole damage) on leaves. Infested seedlings show pitting, skeletonization, and slowed growth. Young plants may wilt, weaken, or die due to repeated feeding. Older plants develop uneven, perforated leaves with reduced photosynthetic capacity. In some species, larvae feed on roots, causing stunted growth and reduced plant vigor.
Season/Trigger Conditions:
* Warm and dry weather
* Early spring or early crop stages
* Weedy fields (preferred breeding grounds)
* Heavy presence of alternate hosts (mustard, radish, nightshade)
* Tender seedlings and young plants
* Light, sandy soils where movement is easy
* Recently tilled fields that disturb soil insects
Natural Resolution:
1. Handpick beetles early in the morning when movement is slow.
2. Use yellow sticky traps to catch adult beetles.
3. Apply neem oil spray every 5–7 days to reduce feeding.
4. Remove badly damaged leaves or seedlings.
5. Encourage natural predators like ground beetles and spiders.
6. Use trap crops (radish or mustard) to divert the insects.
7. Maintain field hygiene by removing weeds that host the beetles.
Chemical Resolution:
Use any ONE of the following insecticides (as per recommended dosage):

* Imidacloprid 17.8% SL – Systemic control
* Thiamethoxam 25% WG – Strong early-season protection
* Lambda-cyhalothrin 5% EC – Fast foliar knockdown
* Cypermethrin 10% EC – Effective contact insecticide
* Spinosad 45% SC – Works well on adult beetles

* Remove weeds and alternate hosts regularly.
* Use neem oil or botanical insecticides as regular preventives.
* Avoid planting highly susceptible crops near infested fields.
* Apply organic compost to boost plant vigor and tolerance

* Seedlings showing slowed growth or wilting
* Yellow sticky traps capturing adult beetles

* Seedlings may die, reducing overall plant population
* Reduced plant vigor leads to smaller fruits or tubers
* Severe infestations may cause 20–50% yield loss depending on crop
Stage of Plant Growth Affected: Most damaging to seedlings and early growth stages, but can affect plants at any stage.
Region/Geography:
Common worldwide, especially in:

* India
* Southeast Asia
* Africa
* North & South America
* Europe
* Mediterranean regions
Cultural control:
Cultural practices to reduce Flea Beetle attacks:

* Use proper crop rotation with non-host crops.
* Mulch around plants to hinder beetle movement and egg-laying.
* Use trap crops like radish, mustard, or turnip to attract beetles away from the main crop.
* Maintain weed-free fields, especially Mustard family weeds (Crucifers).
* Plant seedlings slightly later when beetle populations decline.
* Intercrop with strong-smelling plants (basil, mint, onion) to repel beetles.
* Avoid excessive tilling which exposes larvae and increases pest activity.
* Promote beneficial insects by reducing unnecessary pesticide use.
* Use reflective mulches to deter beetles from landing.

Season/Trigger Conditions:

4. Improve soil moisture retention with compost or organic matter.
5. Increase humidity gently using mulching (not overhead watering).
6. Prune lightly to balance fruit load and reduce stress.
7. Correct nutrient imbalance with calcium-rich amendments.
8. Protect fruits from sudden rainfall if grown in polyhouse/shade.

Plant Part Affected: Older leaves (primary), lower foliage, sometimes stems
Symptoms Description: Magnesium deficiency causes interveinal chlorosis (yellowing between veins) on older leaves while the veins remain green. Season/Trigger Conditions:
* Acidic soils (low pH)
* Light, sandy soils with poor nutrient retention
* Excess potassium or calcium competing with Mg uptake
* Over-irrigation causing nutrient leaching
* Cold, wet soil reducing root absorption
* Rapid plant growth outpacing nutrient supply
* Heavy fruit load increasing magnesium demand
Natural Resolution:
1. Reduce excessive irrigation to prevent nutrient leaching.
2. Improve soil organic matter to enhance nutrient-holding capacity.
3. Remove severely damaged leaves to encourage new growth.
4. Maintain proper soil moisture—avoid drought and waterlogging.
5. Apply mulch to stabilize soil temperature and moisture.
6. Improve soil pH by adding lime if soil is too acidic.
7. Reduce potassium-heavy fertilizers temporarily.
Chemical Resolution:
Apply any ONE of the following magnesium sources:

* Magnesium Sulfate (Epsom Salt) – 1% foliar spray
* Magnesium Sulfate soil application – 25–50 kg/ha
* Dolomite Lime (for acidic soils)
* Magnesium Nitrate (1% spray)
* Cal-Mag supplements (Calcium + Magnesium)

* Avoid over-irrigation that leads to leaching.

Symptoms Description: Phomopsis Blight begins with small, circular, dark-brown spots on leaves that enlarge and develop gray centers with dark margins. * Frequent rainfall or overhead irrigation

* Infected plant debris left in the soil

* Fruit injury from pests or mechanical damage

5. Apply neem oil or bio-fungicidal sprays weekly to slow spread.
6. Collect and destroy fallen infected fruits/debris.
7. Improve soil drainage to prevent humidity buildup.
8. Rotate crops with non-host plants for 2–3 years.

Category:
Physiological / Viral / Phytoplasma Disorder
(Depending on cause)
Plant Part Affected: Leaves (mainly), young shoots, branches, occasionally flowers
Symptoms Description: Small Leaf Disease is characterized by the formation of abnormally small, narrow, and pale leaves. Leaf blades remain underdeveloped while veins become disproportionately prominent. Plants show excessive branching (witches’-broom effect), stunted growth, shortened internodes, and poor flowering. Leaves may appear leathery, thick, or spoon-shaped. Severe infections cause significant growth reduction and poor yield. Caused by viral/phytoplasma infection, nutrient imbalance (Zn/B deficiency), or stress conditions.
Season/Trigger Conditions:
* High populations of vectors (leafhoppers, jassids, whiteflies)
* Warm weather with high humidity
* Nutrient deficiencies (Zinc, Boron)
* Soil pH imbalance
* Continuous cropping of susceptible varieties
* Plant stress due to drought or poor soil conditions
* Presence of infected weeds
* Nursery contamination
Natural Resolution:
(Works for nutrient/stress-related small leaves, not for viral/phytoplasma)

1. Apply micronutrient sprays (Zn, B) to correct deficiency.
2. Improve irrigation schedule to reduce stress.
3. Remove damaged leaves to promote new growth.
4. Enhance soil with compost or organic matter.
5. Adjust soil pH if too acidic/alkaline.
6. Remove weeds and alternate hosts nearby.
7. Use neem oil or soap spray to reduce vector pressure.

⚠️ Virus/phytoplasma-infected plants do NOT recover naturally.

* Reduced flowering and fruit set

* Early fruit development

Plant Part Affected: Leaves, stems, young shoots, flowers, fruits (indirect effects)
Symptoms Description: Tobacco Mosaic Virus causes a distinct mosaic pattern of light and dark green areas on leaves. Leaves may become mottled, distorted, wrinkled, or narrowed. Plants show stunted growth, reduced leaf size, and delayed flowering. Fruits may appear smaller, unevenly ripened, and discolored. TMV is extremely stable and spreads easily through contaminated hands, tools, soil, infected plant material, and mechanical contact, not primarily by insects.
Season/Trigger Conditions:
* Warm temperatures (20–30°C)
* Mechanical injury to leaves
* Handling plants after smoking tobacco
* Contaminated tools, hands, clothing
* Continuous cropping of solanaceous plants
* Presence of infected crop debris
* Lack of sanitation practices
Natural Resolution:
⚠️ Virus cannot be cured — only managed.

1. Remove infected leaves or entire plants to prevent spread.
2. Avoid touching healthy plants after handling infected ones.
3. Wash hands and tools with soap or 1% bleach solution.
4. Maintain good airflow by pruning dense foliage.
5. Disinfect seed trays and nursery tools.
6. Use neem oil or botanical sprays to discourage mechanical spread via pests.
7. Remove weeds that can harbor TMV.
8. Provide supportive nutrition to strengthen plant growth.
Chemical Resolution:
⚠️ There is NO chemical cure for TMV.
Chemicals only help control pests that may assist in mechanical spread.

You may use:

* Neem oil (2–3%) – preventive surface protection
* Insecticidal soap – reduce vector activity
* Sanitizing agents (1% bleach, disinfectants) for tools and hands
Preventive Measures:
* Use certified virus-free seeds and seedlings.
* Wash hands thoroughly before handling plants.
* Sterilize tools with bleach or alcohol before use.
* Do not use tobacco products near plants.
* Remove and destroy infected plants immediately.
* Avoid touching plants when leaves are wet.
* Maintain good spacing to minimize leaf contact.
* Disinfect nursery trays, pots, and tools regularly.
* Use resistant/tolerant varieties if available.
Detection Method:
* Mosaic (light–dark green) leaf patterns
* Leaf wrinkling, distortion, narrowing
* Stunted plant growth
* Poor fruit set and uneven fruit ripening
* Lab tests (ELISA, PCR) for virus confirmation
* Rub-inoculation tests in research labs
Impact on Yield:
* Reduced leaf area → low photosynthesis
* Stunted plant growth and poor vigor
* Deformed fruits with color-breaking
* Lower fruit size and reduced marketability
* Yield loss ranges from 20–80% depending on infection stage
Stage of Plant Growth Affected:
All stages can be affected, but most damaging when infection occurs during:

* Seedling stage
* Early vegetative stage
* Early flowering
Region/Geography:
Occurs worldwide, especially in:

* India
* Southeast Asia
* Africa
* Europe
* North & South America

TMV is common in both tropical and temperate regions due to its strong survival capability.
Cultural control:
* Practice crop rotation with non-host crops for at least 2–3 years.
* Solarize soil to reduce virus presence.
* Remove infected plant debris immediately after harvest.
* Maintain weed-free fields (weeds can harbor TMV).
* Avoid excessive pruning to limit mechanical transmission.
* Use gloves when handling plants.
* Keep nurseries isolated from infected fields.
* Implement strict sanitation protocols for workers and tools.

Plant Part Affected: Leaves (primary), tender shoots, buds, flowers, young fruits
Symptoms Description: Tobacco Caterpillar causes severe defoliation by feeding on leaves, leaving irregular holes, skeletonized leaves, and complete leaf destruction in heavy infestations. * Dense foliage with high humidity
* Presence of alternate host weeds
* Overuse of nitrogen fertilizers
* Poor field sanitation

Natural Resolution:
1. Handpick early-stage larvae and egg masses.

5. Spray neem oil (3%) or NSKE 5% weekly to reduce early larval stages.
6. Maintain weed-free surroundings to remove breeding sites.
7. Deep plough soil to expose pupae.

* Spinosad 45% SC – Strong stomach poison for caterpillars
* Flubendiamide 20% WG – Long-lasting control
* Chlorantraniliprole 18.5% SC – Highly effective on all larval stages
* Lambda-cyhalothrin 5% EC – Fast knockdown
* Indoxacarb 14.5% SC – Good control for mature larvae

* Poor flowering and fruit development

All stages, but most severe during:

* Vegetative stage (heavy defoliation)
* Flowering stage
* Early fruit development

Common in:

Plant Part Affected: Roots, stems, vascular system, leaves (indirect wilt symptoms)
Symptoms Description: Verticillium Wilt causes a gradual wilting of lower leaves, followed by yellowing and browning. Leaves may curl upward before drying and falling. The disease progresses upward, causing partial plant wilt. Cutting the stem reveals light brown to dark streaks in the vascular tissue. Plants become stunted, weak, and produce fewer flowers and fruits. Unlike bacterial wilt, wilting is slow and progressive, often occurring on one side of the plant.
Season/Trigger Conditions:
* Cool to warm soil temperatures (20–28°C)
* Dry weather followed by irrigation
* Soil with long-term Verticillium contamination
* Poor crop rotation practices
* Low soil fertility
* Water stress (drought increases severity)
* Plant injury at roots allowing fungal entry
Natural Resolution:
(Only for mild cases; disease is systemic and persists in soil)

1. Remove wilted leaves to reduce plant stress.
2. Improve irrigation consistency to avoid drought stress.
3. Add compost or organic matter to improve soil health.
4. Mulch to stabilize soil moisture.
5. Prune affected branches to improve airflow and sunlight.
6. Remove nearby weeds and alternate hosts.
7. Avoid working around plants when soil is wet (reduces spread).

⚠️ Severe infections do not recover, and soil remains infected for years.
Chemical Resolution:
⚠️ No chemical completely cures Verticillium Wilt, but soil and root-zone fungicides provide partial suppression.

Possible management options include:

* Carbendazim drenching – partial suppression
* Trichoderma viride / harzianum – biological control
* Soil solarization for 4–6 weeks before planting
* Bio-fungicide drenches (Pseudomonas fluorescens)

Important: Fungicides are far less effective once fungus reaches vascular tissues.
Preventive Measures:
* Use resistant or tolerant varieties whenever available.
* Ensure proper crop rotation for 3–4 years with non-host crops.
* Improve soil fertility with compost and organic matter.
* Avoid drought stress — water consistently.
* Avoid root injury caused by cultivation tools.
* Remove infected plants and burn them away from the field.
* Avoid planting susceptible crops in infected soil.
* Sterilize tools to prevent spread.
Detection Method:
* Gradual wilting starting from lower leaves
* One-sided wilting on stems or branches
* Yellowing, browning, leaf curl
* Browning of vascular tissue when stem is cut longitudinally
* Stunted growth and reduced fruiting
* Laboratory confirmation through fungal isolation / PCR
Impact on Yield:
* Stunted plants with weak growth
* Reduced flowering and fruit setting
* Smaller and fewer fruits
* Severe infections cause 20–70% yield loss
* Soil remains contaminated, affecting future crops
Stage of Plant Growth Affected:
All stages, but most severe during:

* Vegetative stage
* Flowering stage
* Early fruiting
Region/Geography:
Verticillium wilt occurs worldwide, especially in:

* India
* USA
* Europe
* Canada
* Southeast Asia
* Mediterranean regions

Common in soils used repeatedly for solanaceous crops.
Cultural control:
* Practice deep ploughing to bury infected residues.
* Grow non-host crops like cereals or grasses to reduce soil inoculum.
* Use solarization during hot months to kill soil fungi.
* Improve drainage — Verticillium thrives in dry but compacted soils.
* Apply thick organic mulch to promote beneficial microbes.
* Remove and destroy infected plants early.
* Intercrop with repellent or resistant varieties when possible.
* Add well-rotted compost to enhance soil microbial activity.

Plant Part Affected: Stems, leaves, flowers, fruits (especially tender or overripe tissues)
Symptoms Description: Wet Rot begins as soft, water-soaked lesions on stems or fruits. Affected tissues become mushy, slimy, and emit a foul smell. Lesions expand rapidly under humid conditions. Fruits collapse, leak fluid, and develop wet, slimy, rotten patches. In fungal wet rot (Choanephora), black pin-headed fungal structures appear on rotting tissues. Leaves may droop and collapse if rot reaches nodes. The disease spreads fast in rainy and humid seasons.
Season/Trigger Conditions:
* High humidity & continuous rainfall
* Waterlogging or poor field drainage
* Overhead irrigation
* Injured fruits/stems that allow pathogen entry
* Dense canopy with poor airflow
* Warm temperatures (25–32°C)
* Presence of decaying plant residues
Natural Resolution:
1. Remove and destroy infected fruits, stems, and debris immediately.
2. Improve airflow by pruning dense foliage.
3. Reduce irrigation — avoid wetting foliage.
4. Provide support to plants to prevent fruits touching soil.
5. Increase sunlight exposure to reduce moisture buildup.
6. Apply neem oil (2–3%) or botanical fungicides weekly.
7. Improve soil drainage to prevent water stagnation.
8. Use mulch to prevent soil splash onto fruits.
Chemical Resolution:
Use ONE of the following fungicides / bactericides (as per recommended dosage):

* Copper Oxychloride 50% WP – Effective against early infections
* Chlorothalonil 75% WP – Broad-spectrum protection
* Mancozeb 75% WP – Protects against fungal wet rot
* Metalaxyl + Mancozeb – Useful if oomycetes are involved
* Streptocycline + Copper fungicide – For bacterial soft rot suppression
* Azoxystrobin 250 SC – Strong systemic + protective action

Spray interval: Every 7–10 days during humid weather.
Important: Remove decayed material before spraying.
Preventive Measures:
* Maintain proper plant spacing for airflow.
* Avoid overhead irrigation; water at base only.
* Train plants so fruits do not contact soil.
* Remove decaying plant residues from the field.
* Harvest fruits on time; overripe fruits rot easily.
* Use resistant varieties when available.
* Improve drainage using raised beds.
* Apply preventive fungicide treatments during rainy cycles.
Detection Method:
* Soft, water-soaked, mushy lesions on stems/fruits
* Slimy, foul-smelling decomposition (bacterial wet rot)
* Black fungal pinheads (Choanephora wet rot)
* Rapid fruit collapse
* Water-soaked streaks on stems/nodes
* Laboratory culture/microscopy for confirmation (optional)
Impact on Yield:
* Rapid fruit rot → direct marketable loss
* Flower drop and fruit abortion
* Weak plant structure and stunting
* Yield loss ranges from 20–50%, severe cases up to 70%
* High post-harvest losses due to fast rot development

All stages, but most severe during:

* Rainy/humid seasons

* Rotate crops regularly to reduce pathogen buildup.
* Use mulching to reduce soil splash and moisture extremes.
* Support vines and heavy fruit-bearing stems with stakes.
* Remove infected fruits and stems daily during monsoon.
* Avoid injuring fruits during harvesting or handling.
* Ensure good ventilation by pruning lower leaves.
* Solarize soil before planting in heavily infected fields.
* Maintain clean field borders and remove weeds.

Plant Part Affected: Stems, leaves, flowers, fruits, pods, collar region
Symptoms Description: White Mold Disease causes water-soaked lesions on stems or leaves that quickly enlarge. Infected tissues become soft and pale. 3. Reduce irrigation; avoid wetting stems and leaves.
4. Increase sunlight exposure to reduce humidity.
5. Apply neem oil or biological fungicides weekly.
6. Remove soil or mulch contaminated with sclerotia.
7. Use raised beds to improve drainage.
8. Avoid handling plants when they are wet.
Chemical Resolution:

* Thiophanate Methyl – Effective on stem and fruit rot
* Prochloraz – Broad-spectrum fungal control

* Iprodione 50% WP – Strong protective & curative action
* Fludioxonil – Excellent for rot prevention

Category:

Plant Part Affected: Leaves (primary), shoots, stems (indirect), whole plant vigor
Symptoms Description: Yellow Disease is characterized by uniform or patchy yellowing of leaves, beginning from the older leaves in nutrient deficiency cases, or from upper leaves in viral infections. Leaves become pale, thin, and chlorotic, while veins may remain green (interveinal chlorosis). Plants show reduced growth, weak stems, poor flowering, and delayed fruit development. * Stress conditions (heat, root damage, transplant shock)

3. Improve irrigation schedule—avoid overwatering.
4. Enhance soil health with compost and organic matter.
5. Increase sunlight exposure and airflow.
6. Remove yellowed leaves to promote new growth.
